Now, putting all together into a single Fortran program. The code would be:

program main
    implicit none
    integer*8 :: x, newNumber
    character(len=20) :: input_str, newNumberStr
    integer, parameter :: max_digits = 20
    integer :: processed_digits(max_digits)
    integer :: index, i, n, bills
    integer :: digits(22) !
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
input_str
    read(input_str,*) x

    ! Process first part
    index = 0
    do while (x > 0)
        integer :: r = mod(x, 10)
        integer :: processed_r
        if (9 - r < r) then
            if (x/10 == 0 .and. (9 - r) == 0) then
                processed_r = r
            else
                processed_r = 9 - r
            end if
        else
            processed_r = r
        end if
        processed_digits(index) = processed_r
        index = index + 1
        x = x / 10
    end do

    ! Compute newNumber
    newNumber = 0
    do i = 0, index-1
        newNumber = newNumber + processed_digits(i) * 10**i
    end do

    ! Convert newNumber to string
    write(newNumberStr, '(i0)') newNumber
    newNumberStr = adjustl(newNumberStr)
    n = len_trim(newNumberStr)

    ! Process second part
    digits = 0 do i = 1, n
        digits(i-1) = ichar(newNumberStr(n - i + 1:n - i + 1)) - ichar('0')
    end do

    bills = 0
    do i = 0, n
        if (digits(i) == 10) then
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            digits(i) = 0
        end if
        if (digits(i) < 5) then
            bills = bills + digits(i)
        else if (digits(i) == 5) then
            if (digits(i+1) >= 5) then
                digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            end if
            bills = bills + 5
        else
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            bills = bills + (10 - digits(i)) end if
    end do

    !

Now, putting all together into a single Fortran program.

The code would be:

program main
    implicit none
    integer*8 :: x, newNumber
    character(len=20) :: input_str, newNumberStr
    integer, parameter :: max_digits = 20
    integer :: processed_digits(max_digits)
    integer :: index, i, n, bills
    integer :: digits(22) ! n can be up to 20, so n+2 is 22

    ! Read input
    read(*,'(a)',advance='no') input_str
    read(input_str,*) x

    ! Process first part
    index = 0
    do while (x > 0)
        integer :: r = mod(x, 10)
        integer :: processed_r
        if (9 - r < r) then
            if (x/10 == 0 .and. (9 - r) == 0) then
                processed_r = r
            else
                processed_r = 9 - r
            end if
        else
            processed_r = r
        end if
        processed_digits(index) = processed_r
        index = index + 1
        x = x / 10
    end do

    ! Compute newNumber
    newNumber = 0
    do i = 0, index-1
        newNumber = newNumber + processed_digits(i) * 10**i
    end do

    ! Convert newNumber to string
    write(newNumberStr, '(i0)') newNumber
    newNumberStr = adjustl(newNumberStr)
    n = len_trim(newNumberStr)

    ! Process second part
    digits = 0
    do i = 1, n
        digits(i-1) = ichar(newNumberStr(n - i + 1:n - i + 1)) - ichar('0')
    end do

    bills = 0
    do i = 0, n
        if (digits(i) == 10) then
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            digits(i) = 0
        end if
        if (digits(i) < 5) then
            bills = bills + digits(i)
        else if (digits(i) == 5) then
            if (digits(i+1) >= 5) then
                digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            end if
            bills = bills + 5
        else
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            bills = bills + (10 - digits(i))
        end if
    end do

    ! Output the result
    print*, bills

end program main

Wait, but in the second part's digits array, I set it to 22 elements (since max_digits is 20, so n can be up to 20, so n+2 is 22). That should be sufficient.

Testing the code with the examples above should work.

Potential issues:

- The first part's loop may have index exceeding max_digits. But since max_digits is 20, which is more than enough for 64-bit numbers (max 19 digits), it's okay.

- The second part's digits array size is 22, which is sufficient for n up to 20.

- The read statement for input_str uses advance='no' to prevent the next read from skipping a line? Or maybe not necessary. The 'a' format reads until the end of the line, so perhaps it's okay.

Alternatively, using read(*,*) input_str may not read properly if the input has leading or trailing spaces. Using read(*,'(a)') is better.

The code should work as intended.
